data.activity:
Field Experience:

Extensive Geological field work in Himalaya from Jammu & Kashmir, Himachal Pradesh, Uttarakhand, Sikkim, Arunachal Pradesh, Nagaland and Mizoram; Central India & Delhi.

  • Areas explored in Arunachal Pradesh are from Bhalukpong where MBT is clearly visible, to Tawang where Paro group of rocks (Gneisses) are visible in the N-S transect. While in the E-W trend the places that have been explored are Kameng, Subansiri, Disang and Lohit valley where rocks of Ladakh plutionic groups are also visible.
  • While in Nagaland (From Dimapur to Kohima) and Mizoram, the Sandstones, Siltstones and Shale of Disang, Brail and Tipam are clearly visible along the road transects.
  • Sikkim is the most beautiful place with scenic Tsangpo Lake in eastern side bordering China and Bhutan. Tista flows across various rock types such as Augen Gneisses in Mangan, Rangpo area, Calc-Silicates in Rongli side with copper enrichment in Singtam area and Lingtse gneisses are seen in Gangtok area.
  • Uttarakhand and Himachal area were explored mainly for site selection for hydro electric power plants, dam, weir, HRT, quarry site. Most places along Alaknanda, Bhilangna, Mandakini rivers are covered in Uttarakhand. While in Himachal the geological studies were carried out mostly along Sutlej River. Other places being Manali, Rohtang (both have high grade metamorphic), Keylong, Tandi, Seli, Dugar (Low grade metamorphic).
  • Landslide/ Slope stability studies were carried out in Jammu area from Batote (Mudstones of Muree formations), Prem Nagar (Serichite Schists), Doda (low grade metamorphics), Urnihal (Gneisses), Kishtwar (Lesser Himalaya sequence). GPR and resistivity studies were also carried out on landslides whose total station survey was also done.
  • Field Trip for Ground Water Sampling with on-spot testing with Geophysical surveys, in Chattisgarh, was done from Rajnandgaon (Sandstones), Khairagarh (volcanics), Dongargarh (Granites) Ambagarh Chowki (Genisses), Kaudikasa (Rhyolites), Bodal (Uranium mines in Basaltic terrain), Manpur, Mohla (Igneous rocks) and Kanker.
  • Geophysical, geotechnical, utility, and archaeological mapping in Delhi, Jodhpur, Konark area. GPR survey of Imja lake moraine (Near Mt. Everest base camp), Khumbu region, Nepal.

data.interests:
Nanomaterials Science

  • Nanodrugs delivery systems

  • Biosensors

  • Micro porous membranes

A major focus is the study and development of varied drugs delivers systems, particularly engineered lipids, polymers; metal organic frame works.

The Work progress in several areas includes:

  • Creating new approaches for delivering drugs across complex barriers in the body such as the blood-brain barrier.

  • Developing controlled release systems that can be pH, magnetically, temperature, triggered to release drug.

  • Synthesizing new biodegradable polymeric delivery systems which will ultimately be absorbed by the body

  • Studying applications of these systems including the development of effective long-term delivery systems for insulin, cancer and alzimers drugs.

  • Biosensors focused on electrochemical sensors.

  • Energy storage devices.

data.activity:
Project.

1. Development of Adaptive Unstructured Angular Discretisation Grid for the Finite Volume Method of Radiative Transfer Equation for Collimated Beam Radiation      

It is a general myth that the radiation heat transfer is only important at very high-temperature applications. However, This is not true. In general, the radiation plays equally important role in the natural convection problems. The radiation heat transfer problems are treated in two ways (1) Surface to Surface radiation (2) Radiation in participating medium. The former way of analysis is relatively simple whereas later one is complex in all aspects, i.e., mathematically, numerically, physics, etc. The radiation problem can also be categories as diffuse and collimated beam radiation. The radiation problem from elevated temperature can be treated as diffuse radiation problem, whereas radiation energy traveling in a particular direction belongs to collimated beam radiation category. The radiation problems from optics to biomedical field belong to collimated beam problem. The solar radiation is also an example of collimated beam radiation. 

The radiation heat transfer can be modeled by an integrodifferential equation known as Radiative Transfer Equation (RTE). This equation represents radiation energy conservation in a direction. To achieve an accurate solution, one need to solve RTE numerically in many directions but need to limit the number of directions by keeping the computational resource in mind. Many numerical techniques have been developed to solve the RTE. The most popular technique is finite volume method for RTE (FvRTE). Along with the CFD domain discretization, FvRTE also discretized the angular domain of 4Pi. The angular domain discretization is regular using the spherical coordinate system with unit radius. This kind of angular discretization produces acceptable results for the diffuse radiation; however, it gives unacceptable results for the collimated beam radiation problems. So FvRTE can not be used for the collimated beam problem in the present form. It is required to improve the angular discretization technique for the collimated beam problems. This project deals to improve the angular discretization so that FvRTE can be used with collimated beam radiation problems.

data.awards:
Talks:

  • Delivered talks on "Approximate Analysis of Multistorey frames subjected to lateral loads" in the 5-day workshop on Recent Developments in Earthquake Resistant Design, organized by the School of Engineering at IIT Mandi during 2-6 July, 2018.

  • Delivered talks on "Non-linear Finite Element Analysis" in the Short Term Course on Finite Element Method for Engineers and Researchers, organized by the School of Engineering at IIT Mandi during 18-22 June, 2018.

  • Delivered talks on "Non-linear Finite Element Analysis" in the Short Term Course on Modeling and Simulation using FEM for engineering applicatios, organized by the School of Engineering at IIT Mandi during 19-23 June, 2017.

  • Delivered lectures on "Finite Difference Method" in the STTP on Advanced Mathemaics for Researchers in Engineering Field (TEQIP-II), organized at IIT Mandi during 24-28 March, 2017.

  • Delivered a talk on the topic "Self-healing concrete" at 3-day (7-9 Feb., 2017) workshop on "Bioengineering measures to control landslides and geo-environmental issues" organized by NIDM at IIT Mandi.

  • Delivered a lecture on "Finite element analysis of moisture transport in concrete", in the short term course on Finite Element Method, Smart Materials and Structures, held at IIT Mandi during 25 – 29 July 2016.

  • Delivered lectures on "Finite Element Analysis" in the Advanced Level Training Programme on Differential Equations with Applications in Engineering (TEQIP-2016), held at IIT Mandi during 1-8 July, 2016.

  • Delivered an invited lecture on "Finite Element Analysis" at JNGEC, Sundernagar on 20 Aug 2016.

  • Delivered a talk on the topic "Fundamentals of Moisture Transport in Concrete and Effects of Wet-Dry Cycles" at Pusa Polytechnic, Delhi on 26-July 2012, in the Short Term Course on "Building Maintenance, Water Proofing and General Repair".

  • Delivered talks in the QIP-CEP course on "Water ingress, implications and water proofing of buildings and structures" organized by the Department of Civil Engineering, IIT Delhi during 16 - 20 July, 2012 on the topics of, (i) Wetting-Drying of RC structures in Tropics and (ii) A Review of Wind Driven Rain Research.

 

    Scholarships/Awards/Honors:

  • Conferred with the“Distinguished New Faculty Award (2017)” for sustained performance of excellence in teaching, research and institute services at IIT Mandi.

  • Was awarded grants by Indian Institute of Technology Delhi and National Buildings Construction Corporation Limited, New Delhi for participating in the 6th Asia and Pacific Young Researchers and Graduates Symposium held at Sirindhorn International Institute of Technology (Rangsit Campus), Thammasat University, Thailand in 2014.

  • Conferred with the“Best Paper Award” by Asian Concrete Federation at the 5thAsia and Pacific Young Researchers and Graduates Symposium held at MNIT Jaipur during 15-16 October, 2013.

  • Received MHRD assistantship for pursuing full time doctoral research at IIT Delhi during July 2009 – December 2011.

  • Secured highest marks in the university (Chhattisgarh Swami Vivekanad Technical University, Bhilai, C.G.) for M.E.(Structural Engineering) 2009 batch.

  • Secured 3rd position in the university (Pt. Ravi Shankar Shukla University, Raipur, C.G.) merit list for B.E. (Civil) 2005 batch.

data.awards:
As PI

  1. Received Early Career Research Award from SERB-DST on "Improving Bio-engineering strategies to achieve soil stability" for 3 years amounting to 51.33 Lakhs, with Dr Shyam K Masakapalli as CoPI.
  2. Received a grant under CARS from SASE/DRDO Chandigarh on "Study of soil-pile interactions under uplift force in model micropiles" for 2 years for an amount of Rs 9.96lakhs, with Dr Kaustav Sarkar as CoPI.
  3. Received SEED Grant from IIT Mandi on "Establishing the change in shear strength of soil due to plant roots: An experimental study" for 3 years to an amount of Rs 6.5 lakhs.

As Co-PI

  1. Recieved grant Rs 5.5 lakhs from SCSTE-HP on "Development and evaluation of landslide risk communication solutions in Mandi Dist. of H.P." for 2 years.
  2. Recieved grant of 27 Lakhs from NDMA on "Development and Evaluation of Low-cost Landslide Monitoring Solutions" for 2 years.

Workshops Organized:

  • Organized a 3 day workshop on "Bio-Engineering Measures for Controlling Landslides and Geo-Environmental issues" by NIDM at IIT Mandi, Feb. 7-9, 2017.
  • Organised a 1 day workshop on "Rainfall Induced Landslides: Mapping, Mitigations and Monitoring" Sponsored by SDMA at IIT Mandi, Oct., 11, 2017
